title: Lord Charles Spencer
text:
Lord Charles Spencer <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">PC</a> (31 March 1740 – 16 June 1820) was a British courtier and politician from the <a href="Spencer%20family">Spencer family</a> who sat in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons">House of Commons</a> between 1761 and 1801.
Background.
Spencer was the second son of <a href="Charles%20Spencer%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Marlborough">Charles Spencer, 3rd Duke of Marlborough</a>, and the Hon. <a href="Elizabeth%20Spencer%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Marlborough">Elizabeth Trevor</a>, daughter of Thomas Trevor, 2nd Baron Trevor. <a href="George%20Spencer%2C%204th%20Duke%20of%20Marlborough">George Spencer, 4th Duke of Marlborough</a>, was his elder brother.
Political career.
Spencer sat as <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="Oxfordshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Oxfordshire</a> from 1761 to 1790 and 1796 to 1801 and was sworn of the <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Most%20Honourable%20Privy%20Council">Privy Council</a> in 1763. He served as <a href="Comptroller%20of%20the%20Household">Comptroller of the Household</a> from 1763 to 1765, as a <a href="List%20of%20Lords%20Commissioners%20of%20the%20Admiralty">Junior Lord of the Admiralty</a> from 1768 to 1779 and as <a href="Treasurer%20of%20the%20Chamber">Treasurer of the Chamber</a> from 1779 to 1782, when that sinecure post was abolished. He was later <a href="Postmaster%20General%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Postmaster General</a> from 1801 to 1806 and <a href="Master%20of%20the%20Mint">Master of the Mint</a> in 1806. From 1806 until his death he was a <a href="Gentleman%20of%20the%20Bedchamber">Gentleman of the Bedchamber</a> to <a href="George%20III%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">George III</a>.
Family.
Spencer married Lady Mary Beauclerk (4 December 1743 – 13 January 1812), daughter of <a href="Vere%20Beauclerk%2C%201st%20Baron%20Vere">Vere Beauclerk, 1st Baron Vere</a> and sister of <a href="Aubrey%20Beauclerk%2C%205th%20Duke%20of%20St%20Albans">Aubrey Beauclerk, 5th Duke of St Albans</a>, on 2 October 1762. They had three sons.
Lady Charles Spencer died in January 1812 aged 68. Spencer survived her by eight years and died in June 1820, aged 80.
